_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

AmeriGas Sparks Terminal - Facility Description



The Sparks LPG Storage, loading and unloading terminal. This Sparks, NV terminal conducts unloading of rail cars, storage of propane, loading of transport trucks.



The facility includes nine (9) above-ground storage tanks with capacity of 30,000 gallons each. It has two (2) 690 Blackmer Compressors used to unload the rails cars.  The terminal has a siding with four rail towers designed to hook to rail cars and unload propane to storage tanks using the Compressors. Compressors withdraw propane vapors from the storage tank and compress them or increase their pressure and discharge into the rail cars to be unloaded. This process slightly decreases the pressure in the bulk storage tanks and increases the pressure in the rail cars by 30 psi (ranges from 60 to 180 psi). As a result, liquid propane flows from rail car to the bulk storage tanks.

There are three (3) bulkheads. Two (2) Bulkheads are used for loading and one (1) for unloading propane. The terminal has two (2) Blackmer Liquid Pumps. There are also nine (9) Plant Wide Emergency Shutdown Buttons that are strategically located throughout the terminal that are used to power off the electrical equipment including pumps, compressors and air compressors, pneumatically charged Emergency Shutdown Valves (ESVs) and internal valves.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy 

The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. The Facility has Terminal Operations Supervisor who is able to immediately assist with a serious

incident by contacting the emergency responders. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country.  The ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.





Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

Worst Case Scenario 

The worst case scenario that was considered was catastrophic release of propane from a 30,000 Gallons Tank. Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst case distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles.

RMP Comp was used as a tool to calculate distance to endpoints of 1 psi overpressure. RMP Comp assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per sec (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient air temperature assumed is 25? C (77 ? F). TNT-equivalent model is used which assumes a yield factor of 10 percent.



Alternative Release Scenario

For alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was considered. The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the hose. Using equation from Appendix C1 (EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis), the calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.03 miles.



Emergency Response Plan

The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement and medical organizations. This is a non-responding facility. Emergencies that require assistance from the local emergency response organizations are handled by contacting emergency responders from the local fire department having jurisdiction. The plan is reviewed periodically to ensure that it remains up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and em

ployees. Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation with site personnel. The employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt notifications are made.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.
